content.description: Awesome traverse with sweet moves that will test your rubber! If you’re looking at Caveman, go right and around the corner until you see some large, shallow dishes. The traverse starts on the right at a “pillar” between dishes. Traverse left using creativity, delicate feet, and some black magic. Finish by climbing up onto the pedistal and topping out.
content.location: If you’re looking at Caveman, go right and around the corner until you see some large, shallow dishes.

content.description: If you loved Caveman (which you should have), you'll love adding another 10 move compression problem to the beginning of it! Seriously, it's full value and awesome. Start under the "belly" of the Caveman holds and squeeze and heel hook your way to the start holds of Caveman (V7). Go do it!
content.location: Start way down below the beginning of Caveman with a right hand pinch and a left hand sloper.

content.description:
Start at the lowest point of the roof finish on

Caveman V6-7

, then climb toward the entrance on huecos, fins, and pinches. Finish at any highpoint.

This is the same problem as Caveman (V7) except after the first few opening moves, instead of going down into the gnarly iron cross gaston crux, follow a slopey crimp rail up and left. The "hidden hold" jug that's deep in the cave before you exit into the finish V3 problem is also on for this variation.
content.protection: It's a long one so a spotter with crashpads following you would be useful.
content.location: Same place as Caveman (V7) except follow holds up and left instead of down and left.

climbs.name: Caveman
climbs.fa: John Bachar; original sit start added by John Long

content.description:
Start by climbing an adjacent boulder on the right side of the cave to access the huge starting jugs, traverse left on STEEEP jugs with bad feet to a cruXy low spot in the roof, finishing up fins and jugs. Downclimb and step off to finish at either the highest jug or at the furthest jug to the left.

Traversing high at the start and utilizing the "hidden" hold, this problem might be V6, traversing low at the start is probably more like V7, avoiding the "hidden" hold is even a bit harder (IMO more esthetic). I think this problem deserves AT LEAST 1 star, prolly 2 because of the uniqueness of the climbing involved.

The sit starts low on the far right of the cave at a pinch and a sloping undercling, about 10 feet below the regular start. Crumbly starting holds have made this start harder over the years. Consensus is that it is a fairly solid V10, holding on for nearly 25 moves being the business.
Start on a bad pinch and sloper, go straight up to prow, and top out.
content.location: On Hit And Miss Boulder facing east which is just south of Caveman Boulder.
